module.p:
Quantity expressions are words and phrases which describe amounts of a substance or of things. Quantity expressions involve appropriate responses to the following kinds of question –
Dè na dh’òl Raonaid de bhainne? How much milk did Rachel drink?
Cò mheud briosgaid a dh’ith Màiri? How many biscuits did Mary eat?

These questions involve non-partitive quantity expressions, where the entity being quantified is indefinite. Related partitive questions are –
Dè na dh’òl Raonaid den bhainne? How much of the milk did Rachel drink?
Cò mheud de na briosgaidean a dh’ith Màiri? How many of the biscuits did Mary eat?

There are two main kinds of quantity expression –
Numeric quantity expressions describe a specific number of things, e.g. còig craobhan five trees, dusan dhiubh a dozen of them, seachdnar seven [people].
Generic quantity expressions do not describe a specific number, but rather some other, non-numeric quantity, e.g. mòran leabhraichean many books, barrachd den airgead more of the money, cus chloinne too many children, a’ chuid as motha de na h-ùbhlan most of the apples.
